posts._title: Pierre-André Boutang – L’abécédaire de Gilles Deleuze AKA Gilles Deleuze from A to Z (1996)
posts.title: L’abécédaire de Gilles Deleuze
posts.excerpt: Quote: Although Gilles Deleuze never wanted a film to be made about him, he agreed to Claire Parnet’s proposal to film a series of conversations in which each letter of the alphabet would evoke a word: From A (as in Animal) to Z (as in Zigzag). These DVDs, elegantly translated and subtitled in English, make …
posts.titleEnglish: Gilles Deleuze from A to Z

posts._title: Peter Guyer & Norbert Wiedmer – Sounds and Silence (2009)
posts.title: Sounds and Silence
posts.excerpt: The ECM (Edition of Contemporary Music) record label is now in its 42nd year, and remains as mysterious and uncompromising as ever. This is primarily due to the fact that ECM is a nearly total reflection of founder Manfred Eicher. In fact, there has never been a label that has enjoyed such long-term success, while …

posts._title: Adilkhan Yerzhanov – Ukkili kamshat AKA The Owners (2014)
posts.title: Ukkili kamshat
posts.excerpt: Two Kazakh brothers are about to lose their ancestral tumbledown house to corruption and nepotism while their little sister loses her capacity to breathe and their mother loses her mind.

posts.title: Kino-Pravda No 9
posts.excerpt: Quote: Between 1922 and 1925, a total of 23 issues of Dziga Vertov’s newsreel series Kino-Pravda (Kino-Truth) appeared (albeit irregularly and in very few copies). Vertov’s goal was to create a kind of “screen newspaper”; the title is a tribute to the newspaper Pravda founded by Lenin. Just like the Kinonedelja newsreel series (1918–19), the …

posts.title: Paparazzi
posts.excerpt: Quote: Paparazzi explores the relationship between Brigitte Bardot and groups of invasive photographers attempting to photograph her while she works on the set of Jean-Luc Godard’s film Le Mépris (Contempt). Through video footage of Bardot, interviews with the paparazzi, and still photos of Bardot from magazine covers and elsewhere, director Rozier investigates some of the …

posts._title: Claude Sautet – Max et les ferrailleurs aka Max and the Junkmen (1971)
posts.title: Max et les ferrailleurs
posts.excerpt: An ex-magistrate (Michel Piccoli) intent on justice joins the police force, then sets up a prostitute (Romy Schneider) and her small-time criminal boyfriend (Bernard Fresson).

posts._title: Thomas Carr – Bobby Ware Is Missing (1955)
posts.title: Bobby Ware Is Missing
posts.excerpt: This suspense film revolves around the crime of child abduction. The parents of the missing child undertake a feverish search for their son. The police are contacted, and a ransom letter is received.

posts._title: Michael Haneke – La pianiste AKA The Piano Teacher (2001)
posts.title: La pianiste
posts.excerpt: Quote: Michael Haneke’s latest torture mechanism is less funny game than daunting debasement ritual. Isabelle Huppert stars as Erika Kohut, an icy piano teacher who goes masochistic when handsome young Walter Klemmer (Benoit Magimel) wants to play with her cold ivory. Huppert responds to Haneke with such straight-faced precision that you might just buy into …

posts._title: Maziar Miri – Saadat Abad AKA Felicity Land (2011)
posts.title: Saadat Abad
posts.excerpt: Quote: A look at the lives of 3 well-off Iranian couples who are ostensibly living an idyllic life and are going to have a get-together for a birthday party. Each couple bearing their own sordid secrets attend the party to find out what follows on the hills of the cold welcome of their host.

posts.title: Marnie
posts.excerpt: Quote: Marnie Edgar is a habitual liar and a thief who gets jobs as a secretary and after a few months robs the firms in question, usually of several thousand dollars. When she gets a job at Rutland’s, she also catches the eye of the handsome owner, Mark Rutland. He prevents her from stealing and …
